text: \eddachapter{Hārbarþsljōþ}{Harbarthsljoth}{The Poem of Harbarth}

The \eddachapterref{Harbarthsljoth} is found complete in the \emph{Codex Regius,} where it follows the \eddachapterref{Skirnismol,} and from the fourth line of stana \eddastanzaref{19} to the end of the poem in the \emph{Arnamagnæan Codex,} of which it occupies the first page and a half.
The poem differs sharply from those which precede it in the \emph{Codex Regius,} both in metrical form and in spirit.
It is, indeed, the most nearly formless of all the Eddic poems.
The normal metre is the Malahattr (cf. {\hyperref[Introduction]{General Introduction}}, where an example is given).
The name of this verse-form means ``in the manner of conversation,'' and the \eddachapterref{Harbarthsljoth's} verse fully justifies the term.
The Atli poems exemplify the conventional use of Malahattr, but in the \eddachapterref{Harbarthsljoth} the form is used with extraordinary freedom, and other metrical forms are frequently employed.
A few of the speeches of which the poem is composed cannot be twisted into any known Old Norse metre, and appear to be simply prose.
How far this confusion is due to interpolations and faulty transmission of the original poem is uncertain.
Finnur Jonsson has attempted a wholesale purification of the poem, but his arbitrary condemnation of words, lines, and entire stanzas as spurious is quite unjustified by any positive evidence.
I have accepted Mogk's theory that the author was ``a first-rate psychologist, but a poor poet,'' and have translated the poem as it stands in the manuscripts.

I have preserved the metrical confusion of the original by keeping throughout so far as possible to the metres found in the poem; if the rhythm of the translation is often hard to catch, the difficulty is no less with the original Norse.

The poem is simply a contest of abuse, such as the early Norwegian and Icelander delighted in, the opposing figures being Thor and Othin, the latter appearing in the disguise of the ferryman Harbarth.
Such billingsgate lent itself readily to changes, interpolations and omissions, and it is little wonder that the poem is chaotic.
It consists mainly of boasting and of references, often luckily obscure, to disreputable events in the life of one or the other of the disputants.
Some editors have sought to read a complex symbolism into it, particularly by representing it as a contest between the noble or warrior class (Othin) and the peasant (Thor).
But it seems a pity to take such a vigorous piece of broad farce too seriously.
Verse-form, substance, and certain linguistic peculiarities, notably the suffixed articles, point to a relatively late date (eleventh century) for the poem in its present form.
Probably it had its origin in the early days, but its colloquial nature and its vulgarity made it readily susceptible to changes.

Owing to the chaotic state of the text, and the fact that none of the editors or commentators have succeeded in improving it much, I have not in this case attempted to give all the important emendations and suggestions.
The stanza-divisions are largely arbitrary.
\eddasepline

comment: \emph{Harbarth} (``Gray-Beard''): Othin.
On the nature of the prose notes found in the manuscripts, cf. \eddacombinedproseref{Grimnismol}{introduction}.
\emph{Thor:} the journeys of the thunder-god were almost as numerous as those of Othin; cf. \eddachapterref{Thrymskvitha} and \eddachapterref{Hymiskvitha.}
Like the Robin Hood of the British ballads, Thor was often temporarily worsted, but always managed to come out ahead in the end.

His ``Journey in the East'' is presumably the famous episode, related in full by Snorri, in the course of which he en countered the giant Skrymir, and in the house of Utgartha-Loki lifted the cat which turned out to be Mithgarthsorm.
The \eddachapterref{Hymiskvitha} relates a further incident of this journey.
translation: Thor was on his way back from a journey in the East, and came to a sound; on the other side of the sound was a ferryman with a boat.
Thor called out:
original: Þo`rr fo`r o`r austrvegi ok kom at sundi einu; o~þrum megum sundsins var ferjukarlinn meþ skipit.
Þo`rr kallaþi:
label: introduction

translation: ``Who is the fellow yonder,{\sep}on the farther shore of the sound?''
original: ``Hverr es sa` sveinn sveina,{\sep}es stendr fyr sundit handan?''

comment: The superscriptions to the speeches are badly confused in the manuscripts, but editors have agreed fairly well as to where they belong.
translation: ``What kind of a peasant is yon,{\sep}that calls o'er the bay?''
original: ``Hverr es sa` karl karla,{\sep}es kallar of va`ginn?''

comment: From the fact that in \emph{Regius} line 3 begins with a capital letter, it is possible that lines 3{\ndash}4 constitute the ferryman's reply, with something lost before stanza \eddastanzaref{4}.
translation: ``Ferry me over the sound;{\sep}I will feed thee therefor in the morning;
A basket I have on my back,{\sep}and food therein, none better;
At leisure I ate,{\sep}ere the house I left,
Of herrings and porridge,{\sep}so plenty I had.''
original: ``Ferþu mik of sundit!{\sep}fo/`þik þik a` morgin:
meis hefk a` baki,{\sep}verþra matr enn betri.
A`t ek i` hvi`lþ,{\sep}a`þr ek heiman fo`r,
sildr ok hafra:{\sep}saþr emk enn þess.''

comment: \emph{Thy mother:} Jorth (Earth).
translation: ``Of thy morning feats art thou proud,{\sep}but the future thou knowest not wholly;
Doleful thine home-coming is:{\sep}thy mother, me thinks, is dead.''
original: ``A`rligum verkum hro`sar þu` verþinum;{\sep}veiztattu fyrir go~rla:
do`pr eru þi`n heimkynni,{\sep}dauþ hykk at þi`n mo`þir se`.''

comment: Some editors assume a lacuna after this stanza.
translation: ``Now hast thou said{\sep}what to each must seem
The mightiest grief,{\sep}that my mother is dead.''
original: ``Þat segir þu` nu`,{\sep}es hverjum þykkir
mest at vita,{\sep}at mi`n mo`þir dauþ se`.''

comment: \emph{Three good dwellings:} this has been generally assumed to mean three separate establishments, but it may refer simply to the three parts of a single farm, the dwelling proper, the cattle barn and the storehouse; i.e., Thor is not even a respectable peasant.
translation: ``Three good dwellings,{\sep}methinks, thou hast not;
Barefoot thou standest,{\sep}and wearest a beggar's dress;
Not even hose dost thou have.''
original: ``Þeygi es sem þu`{\sep}þrju` bu` go`þ eigir:
berbeinn þu` stendr{\sep}ok hefr brautinga go/rvi;
þatki at þu` hafir bro/`kr þi`nar!''

translation: ``Steer thou hither the boat;{\sep}the landing here shall I show thee;
But whose the craft{\sep}that thou keepest on the shore?''
original: ``Sty`rþu hingat eikjunni!{\sep}ek mun þe`r sto~þna kenna;
eþa hverr a` skipit{\sep}es þu` heldr viþ landit?''

translation: ``Hildolf is he{\sep}who bade me have it,
A hero wise;{\sep}his home is at Rathsey's sound.
He bade me no robbers to steer,{\sep}nor stealers of steeds,
But worthy men,{\sep}and those whom well do I know.
Say now thy name,{\sep}if over the sound thou wilt fare.''
original: ``Hildolfr sa` heitir,{\sep}es mik halda baþ,
rekkr enn ra`þsvinni,{\sep}es by`r i` Ra`þseyjarsundi;
baþat hann hlennimenn flytja{\sep}eþa hrossa þjo`fa,
go`þa eina{\sep}ok þa`s ek go~rva kunna.
Segþu til nafns þi`ns,{\sep}ef þu` vill of sundit fara.''

comment: \emph{In danger:} Thor is ``sekr,'' i.e., without the protection of any law, so long as he is in the territory of his enemies, the giants.
\emph{Meili:} a practically unknown son of Othin, mentioned here only in the Edda.

\emph{Magni:} son of Thor and the giantess Jarnsaxa; after Thor's fight with Hrungnir (cf. stanza \eddastanzaref{14}, note) Magni, though but three days old, was the only one of the gods strong enough to lift the dead giant's foot from Thor's neck.

After rescuing his father, Magni said to him: ``There would have been little trouble, father, had I but come sooner; I think I should have sent this giant to hell with my fist if I had met him first.''
Magni and his brother, Mothi, inherit Thor's hammer.
translation: ``My name indeed shall I tell,{\sep}though in danger I am,
And all my race;{\sep}I am Othin's son,
Meili's brother,{\sep}and Magni's father,
The strong one of the gods;{\sep}with Thor now speech canst thou get.
And now would I know{\sep}what name thou hast.''
original: ``Segja munk til nafns mi`ns,{\sep}þo`t ek sekr seak,
ok til alls o/þlis:{\sep}ek em O`þins sunr,
Meila bro`þir,{\sep}en Magna faþir,
þru`þvaldr goþa;{\sep}viþ Þo`r kna`ttu he`r do/`ma.
Hins viljak nu` spyrja,{\sep}hvat þu` heitir.''

translation: ``Harbarth am I,{\sep}and seldom I hide my name.''
original: ``Ha`rbarþr ek heiti,{\sep}hylk of nafn sjaldan.''

translation: ``Why shouldst thou hide thy name,{\sep}if quarrel thou hast not?''
original: ``Hvat skaltu of nafn hylja,{\sep}nema þu` sakar eigir?''

comment: This stanza is hopelessly confused as to form, but none of the editorial rearrangements have materially altered the meaning.

\emph{Doomed to die:} the word ``feigr'' occurs constantly in the Old Norse poems and sagas; the idea of an inevitable but unknown fate seems to have been practically universal through out the pre-Christian period.
On the concealment of names from enemies, cf. \eddachapterref{Fafnismol,} {\eddaproseref[prose]{Fafnismol}{prose1}} after stanza {\eddastanzaref[Fafnismol]{1}}.
translation: ``And though I had a quarrel,{\sep}from such as thou art
Yet none the less{\sep}my life would I guard,
Unless I be doomed to die.''
original: ``En þo`t ek sakar eiga,{\sep}fyr sli`kum sem þu` est
munk forþa þo`{\sep}fjo~rvi mi`nu,
nema ek feigr se`.''

comment: This stanza, like the preceding one, is peculiarly chaotic in the manuscript, and has been variously emended.
translation: ``Great trouble, methinks,{\sep}would it be to come to thee,
To wade the waters across,{\sep}and wet my middle;
Weakling, well shall I pay{\sep}thy mocking words,
if across the sound I come.''
original: ``Harm ljo`tan{\sep}\emph{hykk} me`r i` þvi` \emph{vesa,}
at vaþa of va`ginn til þi`n{\sep}ok va_e`ta o~gur minn;
skyldak launa ko~gursveini þi`num{\sep}kanginyrþi,
ef ek komumk of sundit.''

comment: \emph{Hrungnir:} this giant rashly wagered his head that his horse, Gullfaxi, was swifter than Othin's Sleipnir.
In the race, which Hrungnir lost, he managed to dash uninvited into the home of the gods, where he became very drunk.
Thor ejected him, and accepted his challenge to a duel.
Hrungnir, terrified, had a helper made for him in the form of a dummy giant nine miles high and three miles broad.
Hrungnir himself had a three-horned heart of stone and a head of stone; his shield was of stone and his weapon was a grindstone.
But Thjalfi, Thor's servant, told him the god would attack him out of the ground, wherefore Hrungnir laid down his shield and stood on it.

The hammer Mjollnir shattered both the grindstone and Hrungnir's head, but part of the grindstone knocked Thor down, and the giant fell with his foot on Thor's neck (cf. note on stanza \eddastanzaref{9}).
Meanwhile Thjalfi dispatched the dummy giant without trouble.
translation: ``Here shall I stand{\sep}and await thee here;
Thou hast found since Hrungnir died{\sep}no fiercer man.''
original: ``He`r munk standa{\sep}ok þi`n heþan bi`þa;
fanntattu mann enn harþara{\sep}at Hrungni dauþan.''

translation: ``Fain art thou to tell{\sep}how with Hrungnir I fought,
The haughty giant,{\sep}whose head of stone was made;
And yet I felled him,{\sep}and stretched him before me.
What, Harbarth, didst thou the while?''
original: ``Hins vildu nu` geta,{\sep}es vit Hrungnir deildum,
sa` enn sto`ru`þgi jo~tunn,{\sep}es o`r steini vas ho~fuþit a`;
þo` le`tk hann falla{\sep}ok fyrir hni`ga.
Hvat vanntu þa` meþan, Ha`rbarþr?''

comment: \emph{Fjolvar:} not elsewhere mentioned in the poems; perhaps the father of the ``seven sisters'' referred to in stanza \eddastanzaref{18}.
\emph{Algrön:} ``The All-Green'': not mentioned elsewhere in the Edda.
translation: ``Five full winters{\sep}with Fjolvar was I,
And dwelt in the isle{\sep}that is Algrön called;
There could we fight,{\sep}and fell the slain,
Much could we seek,{\sep}and maids could master.''
original: ``Vask meþ Fjo~lvari{\sep}fimm vetr alla
i` eyju þeiri{\sep}es Algro/`n heitir;
vega ve`r þar kno~`ttum{\sep}ok val fella,
margs at freista,{\sep}mans at kosta.''

comment: Thor is always eager for stories of this sort; cf. stanzas \eddastanzaref{31} and \eddastanzaref{33}.
translation: ``How won ye success with your women?''
original: ``Hversu snu`nuþu yþr konur yþrar?''

translation: ``Lively women we had,{\sep}if they wise for us were;
Wise were the women we had,{\sep}if they kind for us were;
For ropes of sand{\sep}they would seek to wind,
And the bottom to dig{\sep}from the deepest dale.
Wiser than all{\sep}in counsel I was,
And there I slept{\sep}by the sisters seven,
And joy full great{\sep}did I get from each.
What, Thor, didst thou the while?''
original: ``Sparkar o~`ttum ve`r konur,{\sep}ef oss at spo~kum yrþi;
horskar o~`ttum ve`r konur,{\sep}ef oss hollar va_e`ri:
þa_e`r o`r sandi{\sep}si`ma undu
ok grund o`r dali{\sep}dju`pum gro`fu.
Varþk þeim einn o~llum{\sep}o/fri at ro~`þum,
hvi`ldak hja`{\sep}þeim systrum sjau
ok hafþak geþ{\sep}þeira allt ok gaman.
Hvat vanntu þa` meþan, Þo`rr?''

comment: \emph{Thjazi:} this giant, by a trick, secured possession of the goddess Ithun and her apples (cf. \eddacombinedref{Skirnismol}{19}, note), and carried her off into Jotunheim.
Loki, through whose fault she had been betrayed, was sent after her by the gods.
He went in Freyja's ``hawk's-dress'' (cf. \eddacombinedref{Thrymskvitha}{3}), turned Ithun into a nut, and flew back with her.
Thjazi, in the shape of an eagle, gave chase.
But the gods kindled a fire which burnt the eagle's wings, and then they killed him.
Snorri's prose version does not attribute this feat particularly to Thor.
Thjazi's daughter was Skathi, whom the gods permitted to marry Njorth as a recompense for her father's death.
\emph{Alvaldi:} of him we know only that he was the father of Thjazi, Ithi and Gang, who divided his wealth, each taking a mouthful of gold.
The name is variously spelled.
It is not known which stars were called ``Thjazi's Eyes.'' In the middle of line 4 begins the fragmentary version of the poem found in the \emph{Arnamagnæan Codex.}
translation: ``Thjazi I felled,{\sep}the giant fierce,
And I hurled the eyes{\sep}of Alvaldi's son
To the heavens hot above;
Of my deeds the mightiest{\sep}marks are these,
That all men since can see.
What, Harbarth, didst thou the while?''
original: ``Ek drap Þjaza,{\sep}enn þru`þmo`þga jo~tun,
upp ek varp augum{\sep}Alvalda sunar
a` þann enn heiþa himin;
þau eru merki mest{\sep}minna verka,
þaus allir menn si`þan of se`.
Hvat vanntu meþan, Ha`rbarþr?''

comment: \emph{Riders by night:} witches, who were supposed to ride on wolves in the dark.
Nothing further is known of this adventure.
translation: ``Much love-craft I wrought{\sep}with them who ride by night,
When I stole them by stealth from their husbands;
A giant hard{\sep}was Hlebarth, methinks:
His wand he gave me as gift,
And I stole his wits away.''
original: ``Miklar manve`lar{\sep}ek hafþa viþ myrkriþur,
þa`s ek ve`lta þa_e`r fra` verum;
harþan jo~tun{\sep}hugþak Hle`barþ vesa:
gaf hann me`r gambantein,
en ek ve`lta hann o`r viti.''

translation: ``Thou didst repay good gifts with evil mind.''
original: ``Illum huga launaþir þu` þa` go`þar gjafar.''

comment: \emph{The oak, etc.:} this proverb is found elsewhere (e.g., \emph{Grettissaga}) in approximately the same words.
Its force is much like our ``to the victor belong the spoils.''
translation: ``The oak must have{\sep}what it shaves from another;
In such things each for himself.
What, Thor, didst thou the while?''
original: ``Þat hefr eik{\sep}es af annarri skefr:
of sik es hverr i` sli`ku.
Hvat vanntu meþan, Þo`rr?''

comment: Thor killed no women of the giants' race on the ``journey to the East'' so fully described by Snorri, his great giant-killing adventure being the one narrated in the \eddachapterref{Thrymskvitha.}
translation: ``Eastward I fared,{\sep}of the giants I felled
Their ill-working women{\sep}who went to the mountain;
And large were the giants' throng{\sep}if all were alive;
No men would there be{\sep}in Mithgarth more.
What, Harbarth, didst thou the while?''
original: ``Ek vas austr{\sep}ok jo~tna barþak
bru`þir bo~lvi`sar{\sep}es til bjargs gengu:
mikil mundi a_e`tt jo~tna,{\sep}ef allir lifþi,
va_e`tr mundi manna{\sep}und miþgarþi.
Hvat vanntu meþan, Ha`rbarþr?''

comment: \emph{Valland:} this mythical place (``Land of Slaughter'') is elsewhere mentioned, but not further characterised; cf. prose introduction to \eddachapterref{Völundarkvitha,} and \eddacombinedref{Helreith Brynhildar}{2}.
On the bringing of slain heroes to Othin, cf. \eddacombinedref{Voluspo}{31} and note, and, for a somewhat different version, \eddacombinedref{Grimnismol}{14}.
Nowhere else is it indicated that Thor has an asylum for dead peasants.
translation: ``In Valland I was,{\sep}and wars I raised,
Princes I angered,{\sep}and peace brought never;
The noble who fall{\sep}in the fight hath Othin,
And Thor hath the race of the thralls.''
original: ``Vask a` Vallandi{\sep}ok vi`gum fylgþak,
attak jo~frum,{\sep}en aldri sa_e`ttak.
O`þinn a` jarla{\sep}þa`s i` val falla,
en Þo`rr a` þra_e`la kyn.''

translation: ``Unequal gifts{\sep}of men wouldst thou give to the gods,
If might too much thou shouldst have.''
original: ``O`jafnt skipta{\sep}es þu` mundir meþ o~`sum liþi,
ef þu` a_e`ttir vilgi mikils vald.''

comment: The reference here is to one of the most familiar episodes in Thor's eastward journey.
He and his companions came to a house in the forest, and went in to spend the night.
Being disturbed by an earthquake and a terrific noise, they all crawled into a smaller room opening from the main one.
In the morning, however, they discovered that the earthquake had been occasioned by the giant Skrymir's lying down near them, and the noise by his snoring.
The house in which they had taken refuge was his glove, the smaller room being the thumb.
Skrymir was in fact Utgartha-Loki himself.
That he is in this stanza called Fjalar (the name occurs also in \eddacombinedref{Hovamol}{14}) is probably due to a confusion of the names by which Utgartha-Loki went.
Loki taunts Thor with this adventure in \eddacombinedref{Lokasenna}{60} and {\eddastanzaref[Lokasenna]{62}}, line 3 of this stanza being perhaps interpolated from \eddacombinedref{Lokasenna}{60}, 4.
translation: ``Thor has might enough,{\sep}but never a heart;
For cowardly fear{\sep}in a glove wast thou fain to crawl,
And there forgot thou wast Thor;
Afraid there thou wast,{\sep}thy fear was such,
To fart or sneeze{\sep}lest Fjalar should hear.''
original: ``Þo`rr a` afl o/`rit,{\sep}en etki hjarta:
af hra_e`zlu ok hugbleyþi{\sep}vas þe`r i` hanzka troþit
{[}ok þo`ttiska þu` þa` Þo`rr vesa;{]}
hva`rki þu` þa` þorþir{\sep}fyr hra_e`zlu þinni
fi`sa ne` hnjo`sa,{\sep}sva`t Fjalarr heyrþi.''

translation: ``Thou womanish Harbarth,{\sep}to hell would I smite thee straight,
Could mine arm reach over the sound.''
original: ``Ha`rbarþr enn ragi!{\sep}ek munda þik i` hel drepa,
ef ek ma_e`tta seilask of sund.''

translation: ``Wherefore reach over the sound,{\sep}since strife we have none?
What, Thor, didst thou do then?''
original: ``Hvat skyldir þu` of sund seilask,{\sep}es sakar'u alls o/ngvar?
Hvat vanntu þa`, Þo`rr?''

comment: \emph{The river:} probably Ifing, which flows between the land of the gods and that of the giants; cf. \eddacombinedref{Vafthruthnismol}{16}.
\emph{Sons of Svarang:} presumably the giants; Svarang is not else where mentioned in the poems, nor is there any other account of Thor's defense of the passage.
translation: ``Eastward I was,{\sep}and the river I guarded well,
Where the sons of Svarang{\sep}sought me there;
Stones did they hurl;{\sep}small joy did they have of winning;
Before me there{\sep}to ask for peace did they fare.
What, Harbarth, didst thou the while?''
original: ``Ek vas austr{\sep}ok o~`na varþak,
þa`s mik so`ttu{\sep}þeir Sva`rangs synir;
grjo`ti þeir mik bo~rþu,{\sep}gagni urþu þeir þo` li`tt fegnir,
urþu þeir mik fyrri{\sep}friþar at biþja.
Hvat vanntu þa` meþan, Ha`rbarþr?''

comment: Othin's adventures of this sort were too numerous to make it possible to identify this particular person.
\emph{By stealth:} so the \emph{Arnamagnæan Codex;} \emph{Regius,} followed by several editors, has ``long meeting with her.''
translation: ``Eastward I was,{\sep}and spake with a certain one,
I played with the linen-white maid,{\sep}and met her by stealth;
I gladdened the gold-decked one,{\sep}and she granted me joy.''
original: ``Ek vas austr{\sep}ok viþ einhverja do/`mþak,
le`k ek viþ ena li`nhvi`tu{\sep}ok launþing ha`þak,
gladdak ena gollbjo~rtu,{\sep}gamni ma_e`r unþi.''

translation: ``Full fair was thy woman-finding.''
original: ``Go`þ o~`ttuþ e`r mankynni þar þa`.''

translation: ``Thy help did I need then, Thor,{\sep}to hold the white maid fast.''
original: ``Liþs þi`ns va_e`rak þa` þurfi, Þo`rr!{\sep}at ek helda þeiri enni li`nhvi`tu mey.''

translation: ``Gladly, had I been there,{\sep}my help to thee had been given.''
original: ``Ek munda þe`r þa` þat veita,{\sep}ef ek viþr of kva_e`mumk.''

translation: ``I might have trusted thee then,{\sep}didst thou not betray thy troth.''
original: ``Ek munda þe`r þa` trua,{\sep}nema þu` mik i` trygþ ve`ltir.''

comment: \emph{Heel-biter:} this effective parallel to our ``back-biter'' is not found elsewhere in Old Norse.
translation: ``No heel-biter am I, in truth,{\sep}like an old leather shoe in spring.''
original: ``Emkat ek sa` ha_e`lbi`tr{\sep}sem hu`þsko`r forn a` va`r.''

translation: ``What, Thor, didst thou the while?''
original: ``Hvat vanntu meþan, Þo`rr?''

comment: \emph{Hlesey:} ``the Island of the Sea-God'' (Hler = Ægir), identified with the Danish island Läsö, in the Kattegat.
It appears again, much out of place, in \eddacombinedref{Oddrunargratr}{28}.
\emph{Berserkers:} originally men who could turn themselves into bears, hence the name, ``bear-shirts''; cf. the werewolf or loupgarou.
Later the name was applied to men who at times became seized with a madness for bloodshed; cf. \eddacombinedref{Hyndluljoth}{23} and note.
The women here mentioned are obviously of the earlier type.
translation: ``In Hlesey the brides{\sep}of the Berserkers slew I;
Most evil they were,{\sep}and all they betrayed.''
original: ``Bru`þir berserkja{\sep}barþak i` Hle`seyju,
þa_e`r ho~fþu verst unnit,{\sep}vilta þjo`þ alla.''

translation: ``Shame didst thou win,{\sep}that women thou slewest, Thor.''
original: ``Kla_e`ki vanntu þa`, Þo`rr!{\sep}es þu` a` konum barþir.''

comment: \emph{Thjalfi:} Thor's servant; cf. note on stanza \eddastanzaref{14}.
translation: ``She-wolves they were like,{\sep}and women but little;
My ship, which well{\sep}I had trimmed, did they shake;
With clubs of iron they threatened,{\sep}and Thjalfi they drove off.
What, Harbarth, didst thou the while?''
original: ``Vargynjur vo~`ru þa_e`r,{\sep}en varla konur;
skeldu skip mitt{\sep}es ek skorþat hafþak;
o/`gþu me`r i::arnlurki,{\sep}en eltu Þjalfa.
Hvat vanntu meþan, Ha`rbarþr?''

comment: To what expedition this refers is unknown, but apparently Othin speaks of himself as allied to the foes of the gods.
translation: ``In the host I was{\sep}that hither fared,
The banners to raise,{\sep}and the spear to redden.''
original: ``Ek vask i` hernum{\sep}es hingat go/rþisk
gna_e`fa gunnfana,{\sep}geir at rjo`þa.''

comment: \emph{Hatred:} so \emph{Regius;} the other manuscript has, apparently, ``sickness.''
translation: ``Wilt thou now say{\sep}that hatred thou soughtest to bring us?''
original: ``Þess vildu nu` geta,{\sep}es þu` fo`rt oss o`lju`fan at bjo`þa.''

comment: Just what Othin means, or why his words should so have enraged Thor, is not evident, though he may imply that Thor is open to bribery.
Perhaps a passage has dropped out before stanza \eddastanzaref{43}.
translation: ``A ring for thy hand{\sep}shall make all right for thee,
As the judge decides{\sep}who sets us two at peace.''
original: ``Bo/`ta skal þe`r þat þa`{\sep}baugi mundar,
sem jafnendr unnu{\sep}þeirs okkr vilja sa_e`tta.''

translation: ``Where foundest thou{\sep}so foul and scornful a speech?
More foul a speech{\sep}I never before have heard.''
original: ``Hvar namtu{\sep}þessi en hno/`filigu orþ,
es ek heyrþa aldri{\sep}in hno/`filigri?''

comment: Othin refers to the dead, from whom he seeks information through his magic power.
translation: ``I learned it from men,{\sep}the men so old,
Who dwell in the hills of home.''
original: ``Nam ek at mo~nnum{\sep}þeim enum aldro/`num
es bua i` heimis haugum.''

translation: ``A name full good{\sep}to heaps of stones thou givest
When thou callest them hills of home.''
original: ``Þa` gefr þu`{\sep}gott nafn dysjum,
es þu` kallar þa_e`r heimis hauga.''

translation: ``Of such things speak I so.''
original: ``Sva` do/`mi ek sli`kt far.''

translation: ``Ill for thee comes{\sep}thy keenness of tongue,
If the water I choose to wade;
Louder, I ween,{\sep}than a wolf thou cryest,
If a blow of my hammer thou hast.''
original: ``Orþkringi þi`n{\sep}mun þe`r illa koma,
ef ek ra_eþ a` va`g at vaþa;
ulfi ha_e`ra{\sep}hykk þik o/`pa munu,
ef þu` hly`tr af hamri ho~gg.''

comment: \emph{Sif:} Thor's wife, the lover being presumably Loki; cf. \eddacombinedref{Lokasenna}{54}.
translation: ``Sif has a lover at home,{\sep}and him shouldst thou meet;
More fitting it were{\sep}on him to put forth thy strength.''
original: ``Sif a` ho`r heima,{\sep}hans mundu fund vilja,
þann mundu þrek dry`gja,{\sep}þat es þe`r skyldara.''

translation: ``Thy tongue still makes thee say{\sep}what seems most ill to me,
Thou witless man!{\sep}Thou liest, I ween.''
original: ``Ma_e`lir þu` at munns ra`þi,{\sep}sva`t me`r skyldi verst þykkja,
halr enn hugblauþi!{\sep}hykk at þu` lju`gir.''

translation: ``Truth do I speak,{\sep}but slow on thy way thou art;
Far hadst thou gone{\sep}if now in the boat thou hadst fared.''
original: ``Satt hykk mik segja;{\sep}seinn estu at fo~r þinni;
langt mundir þu` nu` kominn, Þo`rr!{\sep}ef þu` liþ of fo/`rir.''

translation: ``Thou womanish Harbarth!{\sep}here hast thou held me too long.''
original: ``Ha`rbarþr enn ragi!{\sep}heldr hefr þu` nu` mik dvalþan.''

comment: \emph{Asathor:} Thor goes by various names in the poems: e.g., Vingthor, Vingnir, Hlorrithi.
Asathor means ``Thor of the Gods.''
translation: ``I thought not ever{\sep}that Asathor would be hindered
By a ferryman thus from faring.''
original: ``A`saþo`ri{\sep}hugþak aldri mundu
glepja farhirþi farar.''

comment: \emph{Magni:} Thor's son; cf. stanza \eddastanzaref{9} and note.
translation: ``One counsel I bring thee now:{\sep}row hither thy boat;
No more of scoffing;{\sep}set Magni's father across.''
original: ``Ra`þ munk þe`r nu` ra`þa:{\sep}ro` þu` hingat ba`tinum;
ha_e`ttum ho/`tingi,{\sep}hittu fo~þur Magna!''

translation: ``From the sound go hence;{\sep}the passage thou hast not.''
original: ``Farþu firr sundi!{\sep}þe`r skal fars synja.''

translation: ``The way now show me,{\sep}since thou takest me not o'er the water.''
original: ``Vi`sa þu` me`r nu` leiþina,{\sep}alls þu` vill mik eigi of va`ginn ferja!''

comment: \emph{Line 2:} the phrases mean simply ``a long way''; cf. ``over stock and stone.''
\emph{Verland:} the ``Land of Men'' to which Thor must come from the land of the giants.
The \emph{Arnamagnæan Codex} has ``Valland'' (cf. stanza \eddastanzaref{24} and note), but this is obviously an error.
\emph{Fjorgyn:} a feminine form of the same name, which belongs to Othin (cf. \eddacombinedref{Voluspo}{56} and note); here it evidently means Jorth (Earth), Thor's mother.
\emph{The road:} the rainbow bridge, Bifrost; cf. \eddacombinedref{Grimnismol}{29} and note.
translation: ``To refuse it is little,{\sep}to fare it is long;
A while to the stock,{\sep}and a while to the stone;
Then the road to thy left,{\sep}till Verland thou reachest;
And there shall Fjorgyn{\sep}her son Thor find,
And the road of her children{\sep}she shows him to Othin's realm.''
original: ``Li`tit es at synja,{\sep}langt es at fara:
stund es til stokksins,{\sep}o~nnur til steinsins,
haltu sva` til vinstra vegsins,{\sep}unz þu` hittir Verland.
Þar mun Fjo~rgyn{\sep}hitta Þo`r sun sinn
ok mun ho`n kenna ho~`num o~`ttunga brautir{\sep}til O`þins landa.''

translation: ``May I come so far in a day?''
original: ``Mun ek taka þangat i` dag?''

comment: \emph{Line 2:} so \emph{Regius;} the other manuscript has ``ere sunrise.''
translation: ``With toil and trouble perchance,
While the sun still shines,{\sep}or so I think.''
original: ``Taka viþ vi`l ok erfiþi
at uppvesandi so`lu,{\sep}es ek get þa`na.''

translation: ``Short now shall be our speech,{\sep}for thou speakest in mockery only;
The passage thou gavest me not{\sep}I shall pay thee if ever we meet.''
original: ``Skamt mun nu` ma`l okkat,{\sep}alls þu` me`r sko/`tingu einni svarar;
launa munk þe`r farsynjun,{\sep}ef vit finnumsk i` sinn annat.''

comment: The \emph{Arnamagnæan Codex} clearly indicates Harbarth as the speaker of this line, but \emph{Regius} has no superscription, and begins the line with a small letter not preceded by a period, thereby assigning it to Thor.
translation: ``Get hence where every evil thing shall have thee!''
original: ``Farþu nu` þars þik hafi allan gramir!''
